dataset.title: Influences of Three Geology Types on Herpetofauna Biodiversity in Shingwedzi Region Kruger National Park

individualName.surName: Dax MacKay and Mary Sparks (editors) Graeme Alexander (resource person)

abstract.para: Surface geology structures are the foundation upon which many biotic community assemblages are based, supplying fine scale micro-habitats for floral and faunal species. Herpetofauna are one of the groups which make direct use of rupicolous habitat for various life stages such as; reproduction, food resources and shelter. The aim of this study was to determine if the geology type of the rock habitat is as important a factor for herpetofaunal biodiversity as is its functional structure. Our study was conducted in the Shingwedzi region of the Kruger National Park were we sampled rock outcrops on intrusive igneous (granite), extrusive igneous (basalt) from and sedimentary (mudstone and sandstone) geology types. The three rock type sites were compared for species richness, species abundance and species diversity. A total of 20 species were recorded from a total of 139 observations of which lizard 8 diversity was highest (10 species) and accounted for the majority of captures (n = 124). No significant differences were found for richness, abundance and diversity comparisons. Our study suggests that herpetofaunal biodiversity is not determined by geology type and that the rock type of any particular habitat does not affect the species expected to be found within that habitat.

section.para: Our study was conducted in the Shingwedzi region of the Kruger National
Park from September 16-18, 2006. Herpetofauna were sampled from 10 rock outcrop
sites occurring on three different geology types; intrusive igneous (granite) from here
on referred to as intrusive, extrusive igneous (basalt) from here on referred to as
extrusive and sedimentary (mudstone and sandstone). Four intrusive sites and three
extrusive and sedimentary sites were selected and surveyed for herpetofauna, by a
team of 21 individuals. Species for each site were recorded in three ways: 1) active
collection which involved rock turning, and leaf and woody debris searching; 2)
observations of species and 3) observations of remnant remains (shedding) over a 30
minute interval. Site surveys were randomly performed at different times of the day
for the three geology types. Post-sampling, sites were returned to as near to pristine
condition as possible.
Species richness, species abundance and species diversity were compared
across the three rock types. Data were input into Primer v5 to ascertain the normality
distribution and run through multi-dimensional scaling at 40 ordinations to generate
an output for richness (the number of different species), abundance (the number of
individuals) and diversity. We used the Shannon-Weiner diversity index which
describes the evenness of abundance in proportion to the species richness. Statistical
analyses were computed; using Statistica 6.0, for species richness and abundance with
a one-way ANOVA test and for species diversity with a Mann-Whitney U test.
